docs.lead_paragraph: The California insurance regulator is preparing lawsuits against several national insurance brokers and companies, people close to the insurance department said yesterday, as investigations into the industry intensify. John Garamendi, the California insurance commissioner, confirmed yesterday that he would file a suit in connection with the bid-rigging and price-fixing schemes laid out by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. Last week, Mr. Spitzer sued Marsh & McLennan, the biggest insurance broker, and had three insurance company executives arrested.

headline.main: In California, Lawsuits Possible in Insurance Inquiry

docs.abstract: California Insurance Comr John Garamendi is preparing lawsuits against several national insurance brokers and companies; confirms he will file suit in connection with bid-rigging and price-fixing schemes laid out by New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer; Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal issues 10 more subpoenas to brokers and insurers around country, raising number he has sent to 30; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The California insurance regulator is preparing lawsuits against several national insurance brokers and companies as investigations into the industry intensify.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marsh Executives Invested In Special Partnership Board members and senior executives of Marsh & McLennan, the giant insurance broker, put millions of dollars into a partnership that profited by buying companies from Marsh and investing in companies that work with it. The disclosures about the partnership may add to the perception that Marsh, which advertises itself as a trusted adviser for insurance buyers and mutual fund investors, has had conflicts. [Page A1.] The California insurance regulator is preparing lawsuits against several national insurance brokers and companies, people close to the insurance department said. [C5.] Lucent Reports an Annual Profit Lucent Technologies reported its first annual profit in four years, benefiting from demand for cellphone network gear and fiber-optic equipment. The chief executive said 2004 was ''a pivotal year'' for the company, which has cut tens of thousands of jobs. [C3.] At Cingular Wireless, third-quarter sales rose 4.9 percent as it added subscribers. [C3.] Trading Trouble Hurts J.P. Morgan J.P. Morgan Chase said poor results in fixed-income trading were behind a quarterly profit drop that surprised Wall Street. [C2.] Chiron Is Vague on Flu Vaccine Executives at Chiron hedged about whether it would be able to return to selling flu vaccine in the United States next year. [C4.] Federal health officials say the nation's elderly should get vaccinated against pneumonia, but supplies of the vaccine, made by Merck, are fragile. [B6.] Major Airlines Report Steep Losses Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and the parent of American Airlines all reported losses amid record fuel prices. [C8.] Disney Unloads Its Store Chain Disney reached a deal to essentially give its struggling chain of retail stores to the Children's Place, the clothing merchant. [C10.] The trial began in a lawsuit filed by Disney shareholders over the $140 million severance package paid to Michael S. Ovitz. [C10.] Stocks Fall as Oil Climbs Again Stocks dropped, hurt by higher oil prices and some weak earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 10.69 points, to 9,886.93, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.43 of a point to 1,103.66. [C11.] Pfizer Profit Up 49% in Quarter Pfizer's third-quarter earnings jumped 49 percent on strong sales of Lipitor and Celebrex. Wyeth said it made a profit in the quarter, while profit at Amgen fell. [C11.] Pen, Ink and Product Placement In what may be a first for an animated show, a cartoon series on Comedy Central will incorporate the names and products of sponsors, including Domino's Pizza, into the action. Viewers will see product placements, ranging from subtle to blatant, in three of seven episodes. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C10.] Small Businesses Are Optimistic Three recent surveys show that entrepreneurs are bullish about the economy but remain cautious. Small Business. [C6.] Is It Too Easy to Get a Patent? In a new book, two professors argue that the patent system has deep problems, with too many patents of questionable novelty being granted. Economic Scene: Hal Varian. [C2.]
docs.snippet: Marsh Executives Invested In Special Partnership  Board members and senior executives of Marsh & McLennan, the giant insurance broker, put millions of dollars into a partnership that profited by buying companies from Marsh and investing in companies...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last May, this page called on the presidential candidates to engage in a serious debate on the federal budget deficit, now $415 billion, compared with the $236 billion surplus when President Bush took office four years ago. What has emerged instead is a pair of dueling tax plans, each of them inadequate to support its candidate's vision of government. President Bush is fixated on making his ill-conceived tax cuts permanent and creating new tax shelters for affluent investors. Senator John Kerry's tax agenda raises money for the government by repealing Mr. Bush's tax cuts for high-income earners, an idea we applaud. But he has promised away everything he'd save for worthy, but expensive, new initiatives. The Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan group, estimates that the stated policies for a second Bush term would result in a slightly larger deficit over 10 years than Mr. Kerry's plan.

headline.main: Why Taxes Have to Go Up

docs.abstract: Editorial in series Campaign 2004: The Big Issues, outlines tax plans presented by Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry and calls them both inadequate to support each candidate's vision of government; says Bush and Kerry, eager not to annoy voters, are operating on premise that nothing need be done now to avert looming dangers of nation's huge financial imbalances; calls this perilously shortsighted
docs.snippet: The dueling tax plans of the presidential candidates do not address the looming dangers of the nation's huge financial imbalances.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 34-year-old man with the initials D.G. complained of chest pain when he walked into the subterranean emergency room at the Moses Division of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx just before 11:30 Monday morning. A couple of dozen people were already in the waiting room, and at first the triage nurse thought the case might not be serious. D.G., a Spanish speaker, said through an interpreter that he had been at the hospital a few weeks ago with similar pain. But in someone so young, such symptoms may only indicate indigestion.

headline.main: In the E.R., Learning to Love the PC

docs.abstract: Montefiore Medical Center, NYC, has invested $120 million in information technology since 1993 and has involved doctors in system design in effort to minimize grumbling about change; after initial resistance, most have come to see system as boon to patient health; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The keyboard is mightier than the whiteboard at an emergency room in the Bronx, where the use of computers is now a staple.

docs.lead_paragraph: When General Motors conducted its quarterly earnings teleconference last Thursday, the first question from Wall Street was not about Cadillac cars or Chevrolet trucks or the company's no-interest financing deals. It was about health care accounting. And that was before G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the auto supply giant Delphi disclosed this week that they were among six companies asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission to provide information as part of an inquiry into corporate pension and health care accounting practices.

headline.main: The Real Consequences of Pension Projections

docs.abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is generally examining whether corporations alter projections for health care costs, pension plan returns and other factors as way of manipulating earnings; agency is looking at automakers like GM and Ford Motor because they have some of largest pension plans and offer medical benefits to huge number of retirees; Northwest Airlines appears to be under scrutiny because of unusual actuarial assumptions that it has factored into its pension calculations; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)
docs.snippet: The S.E.C. is examining whether corporations alter projections for health care costs, pension plan returns and other factors as a way of manipulating earnings.

byline.original: By DANNY HAKIM and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Education Association canceled a threatened strike after the Legislature approved a new health insurance plan that reduces deductibles and out-of-pocket costs for 229,000 active and retired state workers, including 45,000 teachers. Gov. Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, had proposed tripling health insurance expenses for state workers. Albert Salvato (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Teachers Won't Strike

docs.abstract: Kentucky Education Assn cancels threatened strike after Legislature approves new health insurance plan that reduces deductibles and out-of-pocket costs for 45,000 teachers (S)
docs.snippet: The Kentucky Education Association canceled a threatened strike after the Legislature approved a new health insurance plan that reduces deductibles and out-of-pocket costs for 229,000 active and retired state workers, including 45,000 teachers. Gov....

docs.lead_paragraph: Tuition at the nation's public universities rose an average of 10.5 percent this year, the second largest increase in more than a decade, according to the latest annual survey by the College Board. Last year's rise, 13 percent, was the highest. Private universities and community colleges also increased tuition, by 6 percent and 9 percent, in a year when inflation has been about 2.5 percent. The tuition increases at private and community colleges were also among the steepest in a decade.

headline.main: Public University Tuition Rises Sharply Again for '04

docs.abstract: College Board survey finds tuition at US public universities rose average of 10.5 percent this year, second largest increase in more than decade; private universities raised tuition by 6 percent, community colleges by 9 percent in year when inflation is about 2.5 percent; average tuition surpasses $20,000 at private college, $5,000 at public university and $2,000 at community college, although increased financial aid cushions blow; students at private colleges actually paid out about $9,600 in tuition, public university students only $1,300; report notes that rise in merit-based aid and expansion of aid categories often gives larger grants to middle- and upper-income students (M)
docs.snippet: Tuition at the nation's public universities rose an average of 10.5 percent this year, the second largest increase in over a decade.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Bush Health Savings Accounts Slow to Gain Acceptance'' (Business Day, Oct. 13), a bleak future is painted for these accounts, but data and real-life experience suggest otherwise. Several hundred thousand individuals are expected to elect this product by year-end, with significant growth projected for next year. A recent poll conducted for America's Health Insurance Plans suggests that when given a description of such consumer choice plans, 71 percent of respondents have a favorable opinion of them.
docs.abstract: Letter from Karen Ignagni (America's Health Insurance Plans) says health savings accounts are attractive alternative for some individuals (Oct 13 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: With polls showing that Florida is once again too close to call, President Bush on Tuesday assured the state's flu-wary retirees that ''we have millions of vaccines doses on hand for the most vulnerable Americans'' as his administration said that 2.6 million more doses would be available by January. Mr. Bush spoke as the flu vaccine shortage moved to center stage in the campaign and as his secretary of health and human services, Tommy G. Thompson, said that Aventis Pasteur, the only company approved this year to sell flu vaccines, would be able to make the extra doses of flu vaccines available so the total would be about 58 million doses in all.

headline.main: Flu Vaccine Policy Becomes Issue for Bush

docs.abstract: Pres Bush tells retirees in Florida, which polls show is too close to call, that there are 'millions' of flu vaccine doses on hand for most vulnerable Americans; photo; administration announces 2.6 million more doses will be available in January as shortage moves to center stage in his campaign; Sec Tommy Thompson says 58 million total doses, along with stocks of anti-flu drugs, will be enough; Democrat John Kerry asks how administration can protect against terrorism if it cannot get enough flu vaccine; Bush repeats charge that Kerry would move toward government health care and sees 'scare tactics' on issues like Social Security and flu; Kerry campaign notes health plan would be privately run and offers data on threat to Social Security (M)
docs.snippet: Democrats have seized on the vaccine shortage to accuse the administration of being unable to protect Americans - from either illness or terrorism.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and GARDINER HARRIS; David E. Sanger reported from The Villages for this article, and Gardiner Harris from Washington

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Prominent Aid Worker Kidnapped in Iraq Margaret Hassan, the British-Iraqi director of CARE International in Iraq, was kidnapped as she rode to her office, the latest in a string of Westerners abducted. Hours later she appeared in a televised videotape made by her abductors. At least four Iraqis were killed in a mortar attack on an Iraqi National Guard base north of Baghdad. A1 Much of the information provided by the C.I.A. to those prosecuting the war and planning the occupation, proved wrong, just as did the intelligence about Iraq's presumed stockpiles of illicit weapons. A1 Insurgents in a careening, high-speed shootout, tried to assassinate the commander of the Iraqi National Guard in Mahmudiya, south of Baghdad, a day after he identified a man in the custody of American troops as a high-ranking financier in the terrorist network of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. A13 British Charge Radical Cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri, the radical Muslim cleric who faces extradition to the United States, was charged by the British police with encouraging followers to murder Jews and other non-Muslims. A14 Myanmar's Premier Dismissed The military government of Myanmar announced the dismissal of the prime minister, Khin Nyunt, who had publicly been pulling in a liberal direction. A7 Brazil Allows U.N. Inspections The Brazilian government agreed to grant inspectors limited access to a plant Brazil has built to produce nuclear fuel for both domestic use and eventual sale abroad, a step toward resolving a long-standing impasse with the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency. A10 NATIONAL A16-25 Efforts of Interest Groups Change Face of Campaigns An army of interest groups is pumping at least $350 million into get-out-the-vote campaigns that are rewriting the tactics of elections. A1 On the Campaign Trail Vice President Dick Cheney cast doubt on whether Senator John Kerry was strong enough on terrorism and said the nation might one day face terrorists with a nuclear weapon. A20 Mr. Kerry visited Wilkes-Barre, Pa., to talk Social Security and fiscal discipline, accusing President Bush of putting the retirement of millions of people at risk. A20 Kerry and the Catholic Church The Roman Catholic Church's official news service quoted a Vatican official saying John Kerry is ''not a heretic'' by virtue of his stance on abortion rights. A24 A City Tries to Recoup Losses Maytag closed its factory after 50 years in Galesburg, Ill., terminating 1,600 jobs. Now local officials want to recoup tax breaks they granted to keep the company in place. A1 EDUCATION B9 College Tuition Rises Tuition at public universities rose an average of 10.5 percent this year, the second largest increase in more than a decade, according to the annual survey by the College Board. A16 OBITUARIES B10 SCIENCE/HEALTH 2.6 Million More Vaccine Doses Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson said Aventis Pasteur would be able to make 2.6 million more doses than it had originally thought. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-9 Design Flaws Ruled Out In Collapse of Twin Towers Federal investigators who conducted the most extensive building analysis in United States history have largely ruled out a design flaw as a central factor in the catastrophe. A1 Bank Rules to Be Eased Regulators are poised to limit a law requiring small banks to serve poor residents in their own backyards through housing investments and development projects. The law has been instrumental in New York City development. A1 City Cuts Off Rent Vouchers New York City officials, ending a decades-old policy, said homeless families in emergency shelters would no longer be allowed to apply for federal rent vouchers or public housing. B1 Carbon Monoxide Kills 3 An Albanian singer, her 7-year-old daughter and her 60-year-old mother were killed by fumes in their home in Staten Island, officials said. B1 Murder Conviction Tossed A man who committed the only recorded murder in the three-century history of Shelter Island, N.Y., is likely to go free after the state's highest court ruled that he had been convicted on the wrong charge. B1 DINING OUT F1-12 ARTS E1-10 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-7 Red Sox Win and Tie Series Boston beat the Yankees, 4-2, tying the American League Championship Series, 3-3, and becoming the first team in major league history to force a seventh game after trailing in a best-of-seven series, 3-0. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 New Insurance Inquiries The Connecticut attorney general issued subpoenas to big health and auto insurers and providers of employee benefits and California officials are taking steps to end what regulators have said are misleading practices by insurance brokers. C1 Alan Greenspan Defends Debt The chairman of the Federal Reserve defended the big increase in homeowner debt under his tenure. C1 Citigroup Executives Resign Three senior executives at Citigroup were forced to resign as Charles O. Prince, the firm's chief executive, delivered on a promise to improve the bank's sullied reputation. C1 Shortage of Oil Tankers The world's 1,500 oil tankers are all booked up with global oil demand surging, and their owners are charging hefty premiums. C1 Business Digest C1 World Business W1 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: The influenza vaccine debacle; the latest financial services scandal; hiding the refugee problem offshore. Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, William Safire. Crossword E6 TV Listings E9 Public Lives B2 Weather A8
